message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the mass as mobile, well-circumscribed, and firm suggests a fibroadenoma. This is characterized by hypercellular stroma with overgrowth of fibrous and glandular tissues on histological examination. The other options describe histological findings seen in other types of breast masses such as ductal carcinoma in situ (A), invasive ductal carcinoma (C), and lobular carcinoma in situ (D).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the mass matches that of a fibroadenoma, which is a benign tumor of the breast composed of both fibrous and glandular tissue. Histologically, a fibroadenoma will show hypercellular stroma with overgrowth of fibrous and glandular tissues. Dilated glands with 2 cell layers present are seen in ductal carcinoma in situ. Large, pleomorphic cells with associated central necrosis and microcalcifications are seen in invasive ductal carcinoma. Terminal duct lobular units surrounded by dense stroma are seen in lobular carcinoma in situ.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The characteristics of the mass, such as mobility, well-circumscribed shape, and firmness, suggest a fibroadenoma. Histologically, fibroadenomas are characterized by hypercellular stroma with overgrowth of fibrous and glandular tissues. Option A describes usual ductal hyperplasia, Option C describes a malignant breast tumor, and Option D describes lobular carcinoma in situ.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The mass described in the question is most likely a fibroadenoma, which is a benign breast lesion. Histologically, a fibroadenoma is characterized by hypercellular stroma with overgrowth of fibrous and glandular tissues, as described in option (B). Options (A), (C), and (D) are histological features of other breast conditions, but are not consistent with the presentation described in the question.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The characteristics of the mass, including its mobility, well-circumscribed appearance, and firm consistency, suggest that it is a fibroadenoma. On histological examination, fibroadenomas are characterized by hypercellular stroma with overgrowth of fibrous and glandular tissues. Dilated glands with 2 cell layers present is a characteristic of usual ductal hyperplasia, large pleomorphic cells with central necrosis and microcalcifications suggests breast cancer, and terminal duct lobular units surrounded by dense stroma suggest lobular carcinoma in situ.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the mass suggests a fibroadenoma, which is a benign breast tumor composed of glandular and fibrous tissues. Therefore, option (B) is the most likely on histological examination. Option (A) describes ductal hyperplasia, option (C) describes a malignant mass, and option (D) describes lobular hyperplasia, none of which match the characteristics of the described mass.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's age, lack of family history, and characteristics of the mass (mobile, well-circumscribed, and firm) support the likelihood that the mass is a fibroadenoma. Histologically, a fibroadenoma is characterized by a hypercellular stroma with overgrowth of both fibrous and glandular tissues. Dilated glands with 2 cell layers present are characteristic of usual type ductal hyperplasia. Large, pleomorphic cells with associated central necrosis and microcalcifications are characteristic of invasive ductal carcinoma. Terminal duct lobular units surrounded by dense stroma are a characteristic of lobular carcinoma in situ.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the mass suggests a fibroadenoma, which is a benign tumor of the breast that involves overgrowth of fibrous and glandular tissues. Histological examination of a fibroadenoma will show hypercellular stroma with overgrowth of both fibrous and glandular tissues. Dilated glands with 2 cell layers present are seen in mammary duct ectasia, large pleomorphic cells with associated central necrosis and microcalcifications are seen in invasive ductal carcinoma, and terminal duct lobular units surrounded by dense stroma are seen in lobular carcinoma in situ.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the mass (mobile, well-circumscribed, and firm) and the patient's history suggest a fibroadenoma. Histologically, a fibroadenoma is characterized by hypercellular stroma with overgrowth of fibrous and glandular tissues. Dilated glands with 2 cell layers present is a histological feature of atypical ductal hyperplasia, while large, pleomorphic cells with associated central necrosis and microcalcifications suggest breast cancer. Terminal duct lobular units surrounded by dense stroma are seen in lobular carcinoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The characteristics of the mass, including its mobility, well-circumscription, and firmness, suggest a fibroadenoma. Histologically, fibroadenomas are characterized by hypercellular stroma with overgrowth of fibrous and glandular tissues. Dilated glands with 2 cell layers present are characteristic of benign breast epithelial neoplasms, while large, pleomorphic cells with associated central necrosis and microcalcifications are characteristic of malignant breast tumors. Terminal duct lobular units surrounded by dense stroma are seen in sclerosing adenosis.
